questions.text: Soap bubble appearance is a radiological finding in which bone tumour:
questions.solution:
Giant Cell Tumor of Bone

  • Characteristics: Giant cell tumours are lytic, eccentric, and expansile lesions, often surrounded by a thin shell of bone, giving a classic 'soap bubble' appearance in radiology.
  • Option A - Also known as Osteoclastoma.
  • Age group - 20-40 years.
  • Common Locations: Typically arise from the epiphysis of long bones, such as:
    • The lower end of the femur
    • The upper end of the tibia
    • The lower end of the radius
  • Clinical Features:
    • Tenderness on firm palpation.
    • Swelling and pain
    • A distinctive 'egg-shell crackling' sensation may be felt.
  • Radiology - Xray shows expansile lytic lesion in epiphyseal region of bone near joints.

Soap bubble appearance.

  • Biopsy - Spindle cells and multinucleated giant cells
  • Treatment - Excision +/- reconstruction using bone graft, Arthrodesis or Arthroplasty.
  • Prognosis - Recurrence following treatment is a serious With every subsequent recurrence, the tumour becomes more aggressive. May show malignant potential.

Option B: Unicameral bone cyst Shows leaf sign.

Option C: Aneurysmal bone cyst Shows Ballooning cortex with blood filled cavity.

Option D: Adamantinoma shows Honey-comb appearance.

Key Takeaway:

The Rule of 'E' for GCT (Giant Cell Tumor):

  1. Epiphysis: Typically occurs in the epiphyseal region of long bones.
  2. Expansile: The lesion is expansile, leading to the thinning of the cortex.
  3. Egg-Shell Crackling: The lesion may exhibit egg-shell cracking on palpation or imaging.
  4. Eccentrically Placed: The tumor is often eccentrically located within the bone.
  5. Excision: Surgical excision is a common treatment option.

questions.text: A 35 yr old is having expansile swelling with egg shell cracking in the lower end of radius. Bone biopsy confirms it to be giant cell tumour. All of the following modalities can be used for treatment except:
questions.solution:
Treatment Options for Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)

The choice of treatment for GCT is guided by the tumor's location, size, and severity.

Excision

  • Complete surgical removal of the tumor is often preferred when the tumor is accessible and clear margins can be achieved.

Excision with Reconstruction (Option D)

  • Used when extensive bone or joint removal is needed. Common reconstruction techniques include:
    • Turn-O-Plasty: Rotation of bone segments to maintain function.
    • Arthrodesis: Joint fusion to provide stability.
    • Arthroplasty: Joint replacement with prosthetics.
    • Bone Grafting: Filling defects with bone grafts (autografts or allografts).

Curettage with or without Adjuvants

  • Involves scraping out the tumor while preserving the surrounding bone:
    • (Option A) - Cryotherapy: Freezing the tumor cavity to reduce recurrence.
    • Bone Grafting: Filling the cavity after curettage.

Radiotherapy (Option B)

  • Typically used for inoperable tumors or where surgery poses high risks. Radiotherapy helps control tumor growth but is less favored due to the potential risk of malignant transformation.

Amputation (Last Resort)

  • Considered when other treatments fail or the tumor is too extensive, resulting in loss of limb function or severe recurrence.

Option A, B & D: Curettage with cryotherapy, Radiotherapy and Excision with fibula head grafting all three are used in GCT Management.

Option C - Chemotherapy is of no use in GCT.

Key Takeaway -

GCT Management Options: (Chemotherapy Not done)

  • Excision with or without Reconstruction
  • Curettage
  • Radiotherapy
  • Amputation

questions.text: A 12 year girl presents to the ER at night complaining of severe pain in lower third leg with mild swelling. No history of fever, trauma or previous injury. Her parents recollect a similar episode which was treated with Tab. Aspirin by a family doctor. Likely diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Osteoid Osteoma

  • Overview:
    • The most common true benign bone tumor.
  • Pathology:
    • Consists of a nidus of tangled, partially mineralized osteoid trabeculae surrounded by dense sclerotic bone.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Age Group: Commonly occurs between 5-25 years.
    • Commonly Affected Areas:
      • Lower extremities, particularly the tibia.
      • Typically located in the diaphysis of long bones.
      • Posterior elements of the vertebrae are also frequently involved.
    • Symptoms:
      • Persistent, nagging pain, often worst at night.
      • Pain is relieved by salicylates (e.g., aspirin).
      • Minimal or no clinical signs; may present with mild tenderness or a palpable swelling if superficial.
  • Diagnosis:
    • X-ray: Reveals a zone of sclerosis surrounding a radiolucent nidus (usually <1 cm).
    • CT Scan: May be needed to detect the nidus if not visible on X-ray due to extensive sclerosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Complete excision of the nidus along with the surrounding sclerotic bone.
  • Prognosis:
    • Good prognosis; it is not a premalignant condition.

Option A: Osteomyelitis present with fever and inflammatory signs like swelling, warmth, Sequestrum and cloaca.

Option C: Osteoclastoma, Epiphyseal Tumor present in 20-40 years female patient with soap bubble Appearance.

Option D: Osteochondroma are small bone tumors occurs in hand and feet.

Key Takeaway -

Ddx of Pain History:

  • Osteoid osteoma - Nagging night pain; relieved by aspirin; no fever
  • TB - Dull aching night pain; not relieved aspirin; mild fever +nt
  • Rheumatoid arthritis - Morning pain along with stiffness
  • Osteoarthritis - Pain usually occurs in the evening/night after prolonged walking throughout the day

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
UBC unicameral/simple bony cyst- Fallen leaf sign

  • Chordoma

Description:

  • A locally malignant tumor that can sometimes be truly malignant.
  • Believed to originate from remnants of the notochord.

Common Sites:

  • Sacrum.
  • Cervical spine (second most common site).

Ewing's Sarcoma

Characteristics:

  • Highly radiosensitive tumor; responds quickly to radiation but often recurs.
  • Distant metastasis frequently present at the time of diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Local Tumor Control: Radiotherapy (6000 rads).
  • Metastasis Control: Chemotherapy.

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)

  • Generally classified as benign* but tends to recur after local removal.
  • Frankly, malignant variants are also known.

Key Takeaway -

questions.text: A 13 yr old boy presents with pain and swelling in the mid thigh region with no history of trauma or fever. Xray shows cortical destruction with new bone formation in layers in the diaphysis of femur bone as seen in the image below. Probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Ewing's Sarcoma

  • Description:
    • A type of bone tumor that primarily affects the diaphysis (the mid-shaft) of long bones.
  • Common Location:
    • Most frequently occurs in the femur.
  • Age Group:
    • Predominantly affects adolescents.
  • Radiological Features:
    • X-ray Appearance:
      • Lytic Lesion: Characterized by a destructive area in the medullary zone of the midshaft of the long bone.
      • Cortical Destruction: The tumor often leads to the breakdown of the cortical bone.
      • New Bone Formation: Observable as layers of new bone growth.
      • Onion-Peel Appearance: The layered new bone formation gives a distinctive appearance resembling an onion skin.
  • Biopsy - The tumour has sheets of round cells resembling lymphocytes. Often, the tumor cells surround a central clear area, forming a pseudo-rosette
  • .Treatment - Highly radio-sensitive tumor
    • Local Tumor Control: Radiotherapy (6000 rads).
    • Metastasis Control: Chemotherapy.
  • Prognosis - It is very poor. Bone to bone secondaries are very common. With the availability of potent chemotherapeutic drugs, 5-year survival has now improved to 30-40 % from 10 % before.

Option B - Osteosarcoma commonly occurs in the metaphysis of long bones.

Option C - Absence of fever and trauma rules out OM

Option D: Non Applicable.

Key Takeaway-

Ewing sarcoma which mimics Acute Osteomyelitis clinically. Xray shows cortical destruction with new bone formation in layers in the diaphysis of femur bone.

choices.text: Though Ewing's sarcoma is highly radio-sensitive, chemotherapy can be used to treat metastasis
Combination chemotherapy of vincristine, adriamycin and cisplatin is preferred
Combination chemotherapy of vincristine, adriamycin and cyclophosphamide is preferred
Surgical resection is not of much use as metastasis is very common before diagnosis

questions.text: Identify the false statement about treatment of Ewing's sarcoma:
questions.solution:
Ewing Sarcoma Management:

Ewing's sarcoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor (Option A), meaning it responds well to radiotherapy. However, despite this sensitivity, the tumor is known for its tendency to recur and spread.

  • Radiotherapy:
    • The tumor responds quickly to radiotherapy, with a typical dose of 6000 rads used for local tumor control.
    • While radiotherapy is effective in reducing the tumor size, recurrence is common.
  • Chemotherapy:
    • Due to the high likelihood of distant metastasis at the time of diagnosis, chemotherapy is crucial. (Option D)
    • The standard chemotherapy regimen involves a combination of:
      • Vincristine
      • Cyclophosphamide
      • Adriamycin
    • This regimen, known as the VAC regimen (Option C), is administered in cycles, typically repeated every 3-4 weeks.
    • The total treatment course usually spans 12-18 cycles, depending on the patient's response and overall health.
  • Combination Therapy:
    • Effective treatment requires a combination of local control (via radiotherapy) and systemic control (via chemotherapy) to manage both the primary tumor and any metastasis.

Prognosis

The prognosis for Ewing's sarcoma remains challenging, though advancements in chemotherapy have improved outcomes over the years.

Prognostic Features:

  • Recurrence and Metastasis:
    • Ewing's sarcoma is notorious for bone-to-bone metastasis, contributing significantly to poor survival rates.
  • 5-Year Survival Rate:
    • In the past, the 5-year survival rate was only around 10%. However, with the introduction of potent chemotherapy protocols, this has improved.
    • Currently, the 5-year survival rate ranges between 30-40%.
  • Factors Influencing Prognosis:
    • Early diagnosis, tumor size, location, and the presence of metastasis at diagnosis play critical roles in determining the survival rate.

Option A, C & D: All Three are Correct Statements.

Option B: Combination chemotherapy of vincristine, adriamycin and cisplatin is a false option because VAC Regimen Contains Vincristine, Adriamycin and Cyclophosphamide.

Key Takeaway -

Mnemonic - "EWING'S PAIN"

  • E: EWS-FLI1 fusion gene (genetic mutation)
  • W: White ethnicity (more common)
  • I: Involves long bones (femur, pelvis)
  • N: Night pain and swelling (common symptoms)
  • G: Group affected: children & young adults (10-20 years)
  • S: Sensitive to radiotherapy
  • P: Pelvis, ribs, spine (common locations)
  • A: Aggressive nature
  • I: Involves chemotherapy (VAC regimen - Vincristine, Adriamycin and Cyclophosphamide)
  • N: Notorious for metastasis (especially bone-to-bone)

questions.text: Most common site of occurrence of enchondroma is?
questions.solution:
Enchondroma

1. General Characteristics

  • Most Common Benign Bone Tumor of the upper extremity.
  • Age Group: Typically presents in the 2nd to 4th decades of life.
  • Symptoms:
    • Often asymptomatic and incidentally discovered.
    • May present as a pathological fracture.

2. Location and Spread

  • Origin: Arises from the metaphyseal medullary canal and spreads towards the diaphysis.
  • Common Sites (in order):
    • Proximal phalanx of the hand or metacarpal (Option C) > Feet (Option D) > Distal femur (Option A) > Proximal humerus (Option B) > Tibia.

3. Radiographic Features (X-ray)

  • Appearance: Symmetric fusiform expansion of the bone.
  • Key Findings:
    • Endosteal scalloping.
    • Intramedullary calcifications.

4. Histological Features

  • Hand Enchondromas: Noted for their high cellularity.
  • Potential Malignancy: Presence of mitotic figures may indicate low-grade chondrosarcoma.

5. Treatment

  • Primary Treatment: Curettage.

Explanations of Options:

  • Common Sites (in order):
    • Proximal phalanx of the hand or metacarpal (Option C) > Feet (Option D) > Distal femur (Option A) > Proximal humerus (Option B) > Tibia.

Key Takeaway:

Mnemonic - "ENCHONDROMAS"

  • E: Expansion (symmetric fusiform expansion on X-ray)
  • N: Nonsymptomatic (usually asymptomatic, incidental finding)
  • C: Curettage (primary treatment)
  • H: Hands (most common location - proximal phalanx/metacarpal)
  • O: Occurs in the 2nd to 4th decades of life
  • N: Neoplastic lesion from metaphyseal medullary canal
  • D: Diaphysis spread (from metaphysis)
  • R: Radiographic findings (endosteal scalloping, intramedullary calcifications)
  • O: Overwhelming cellularity in hand enchondromas (histology)
  • M: Mitotic figures may indicate low-grade chondrosarcoma
  • A: Asymptomatic pathological fracture (common presentation)
  • S: Secondary sites: Feet, femur, humerus, tibia

questions.text: Which of the following is an important marker of recurrence of osteosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Importance of Serum ALP in Osteosarcoma

1. Diagnostic Marker

  • Serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels are often elevated in osteosarcoma patients.
  • High ALP reflects increased bone turnover, characteristic of the rapid and abnormal bone growth in osteosarcoma.

2. Indicator of Tumor Activity

  • Elevated ALP indicates aggressive tumor behavior.
  • Tumors with high metabolic activity tend to show higher ALP levels.

3. Prognostic Value

  • High ALP at diagnosis is linked to poorer prognosis.
  • Patients with persistently elevated ALP levels typically have lower overall survival and higher risk of metastasis.

4. Treatment Response Monitoring

  • A decrease in ALP levels during treatment suggests a positive response.
  • Persistent elevation may indicate incomplete treatment response or residual disease.

5. Recurrence Indicator

  • Rising ALP levels post-treatment can signal early disease recurrence, prompting further investigations and timely interventions.

Option A: Serum ALP is a useful serum marker in osteosarcoma.

Option B: LDH is a useful serum marker in Ewing's sarcoma.

Option C: Beta-2 microglobulin is a useful serum marker in MM.

Option D: Reversed A/G ratio and normal ALP in multiple myloma

Key Takeaway -

ALP Importance In Osteosarcoma

  • Prognostic Marker
  • Diagnostic Marker
  • Monitoring Marker
  • Recurrence Marker

choices.text: The age of the patient would be around 15-20 yrs
An irregular destruction in the metaphysis of the femur can be seen
Typical sun-ray appearance can be seen as the tumor is growing into surrounding soft tissue
Lytic lesion seen in osteosarcoma is marked by the arrow

questions.text: The image given below is an xray of a patient diagnosed with osteosarcoma. Select false statements.
questions.solution:
Radiological Features of Osteosarcoma

1. X-ray Findings

  • Periosteal Reaction:
    • Codman's Triangle: Triangular elevation of the periosteum seen at the tumor's edge.
  • Bone Destruction:
    • Bony Lesions: Destruction of bone with irregular borders.
  • Calcification:
    • Sunburst Pattern: Radiating spicules of calcified bone from the tumor, often seen in aggressive forms.

2. CT Scan Findings

  • Soft Tissue Mass:
    • Extensive Soft Tissue Involvement: Large, heterogeneous mass extending beyond the bone.
  • Bone Matrix:
    • Mineralization: Heterogeneous mineralization within the tumor.

3. MRI Findings

  • Signal Characteristics:
    • T1-weighted Images: Tumor appears low to intermediate signal intensity.
    • T2-weighted Images: Tumor appears high signal intensity due to increased water content.
  • Invasion:
    • Medullary Cavity Involvement: Tumor extending from the cortex into the bone marrow.

4. Bone Scan Findings

  • Increased Uptake:
    • High Radiotracer Uptake: Reflects increased bone activity around the tumor.

Option A: Epiphyseal growth plates visible in femur and tibia hence the patient has not attained skeletal maturity and would be between 15-20yrs of age.

Option B: Distal femur metaphysis shows irregular cortical destruction with periosteal reaction.

Option C: The lateral view of xray shows typical 'Sun-ray appearance' of the tumour into the surrounding tissue.

Option D: The arrow shows the periosteal reaction with new bone formation and not lytic lesion. Lytic lesions can be seen in GCT.

Key Takeaway -

Mnemonic - "OSCAR HAS BONEs"

  • O: Osteosarcoma
  • S: Sunburst pattern (calcification pattern on X-ray)
  • C: Codman's triangle (periosteal reaction seen on X-ray)
  • A: Aggressive (highly invasive tumor with soft tissue involvement)
  • R: Radiological features (X-ray, CT, MRI findings)
  • HA: High ALP (elevated alkaline phosphatase in blood)
  • S: Soft tissue mass (extensive involvement seen on CT)
  • BONEs: BONE marrow invasion (medullary cavity involvement)

choices.text: Pepper pot skull/ salt and pepper skull

questions.text: Given below is the radiograph of the skull of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma. Identify the characteristic appearance seen in the x-ray.
questions.solution:
Multiple Myeloma Imaging:

1. X-ray Findings

Lytic Lesions:

  • (Option C) "Punched-out" Lesions: Well-defined, rounded bone defects commonly seen in the skull, spine, and long bones.
  • Osteopenia:
    • Diffuse Bone Loss: Decreased bone density throughout affected areas.

Option A: Salt and Pepper skull - Hyperparathyroidism

Option B: Cotton wool skull - Paget's disease

Key Takeaway -

Skull Appearance in disease:

  • Multiple myeloma - Punched out lesions
  • Pagets disease - Cotton wool appearance
  • Hyperparathyroidism - Pepper pot skull/ salt and pepper skull

questions.text: A 35 yr old gentleman presents with complaints of long standing multiple joint pain and stiffness specifically in small joints. He recalls his mother having arthritis and similar complaints as well. All of these will be consistent with this condition except:
questions.solution:
Night pain and stiffness is not seen. Instead Pain and stiffness is seen at Morning.

Rheumatoid Arthritis: Key points

Articular deformities specifically seen in chronic RA are listed in the image given below.

Option A - Hallux valgus is commonly seen in patients with RA.

Option B - Swan neck deformity is seen in RA where there is hyper-extension at PIP joint and flexion at DIP joint of fingers.

Option C - Pain and stiffness in RA is in the morning and not night.

Option D - ESR is usually raised in RA patients.

Key Takeaway -

Night pain/cries and stiffness is typically seen in joint TB and osteoid osteoma. Rheumatoid arthritis patient parent with pain and stiffness at. Morning.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of secondary osteoarthritis of any joint except:
questions.solution:
Secondary Osteoarthritis (OA)

Definition: Secondary osteoarthritis is a type of OA that results from an underlying primary joint disease, which leads to degeneration of the joint. This degeneration often develops years after the initial condition.

Age of Onset:

  • Can occur at any age after adolescence.
  • Commonly affects the hip joint.

Predisposing Factors:

  1. Congenital Maldevelopment:
    • Example: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH).
    • Impact: Abnormal joint development that predisposes the joint to degeneration.
  2. (Option C) Irregularity of Joint Surfaces from Previous Trauma:
    • Example: Post-traumatic arthritis following intra-articular fractures.
    • Impact: Joint surface irregularities lead to abnormal wear and tear.
  3. Previous Diseases Affecting Articular Surfaces:
    • Examples: Joint infections, Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA), Avascular Necrosis (AVN) (Option A).
    • Impact: These conditions damage the articular surfaces, contributing to secondary OA.
  4. Internal Derangement of the Knee:
    • Example: Presence of a loose body due to synovial chondromatosis. (Option D)
    • Impact: Mechanical disruptions within the joint accelerate cartilage degeneration.
  5. Mal-Alignment:
    • Examples: Bow legs, knock knees.
    • Impact: Abnormal joint alignment leads to uneven stress distribution and increased wear.
  6. Obesity and Excessive Weight:
    • Impact: Increased load on joints accelerates the wear and tear process.

Treatment of Secondary Osteoarthritis (OA)

Pharmacological:

  • Analgesics: Acetaminophen for pain relief.
  • NSAIDs: Ibuprofen, naproxen to reduce pain and inflammation.
  • Topical Agents: NSAIDs and capsaicin creams for localized relief.
  • Intra-Articular Injections: Corticosteroids for inflammation, hyaluronic acid for lubrication.

Surgical:

  • Arthroscopy: Minimally invasive repair of joint damage.
  • Osteotomy: Realignment of bones to correct malalignment.
  • Joint Replacement: Total or partial replacement of the damaged joint.
  • Arthrodesis: Joint fusion (small joints)

Option A, C & D: AVN, Intra Articular Fracture and loose body all three can cause Secondary arthritis.

Key Takeaway -

Secondary OA Causes

  • AVN
  • Post traumatic following Intra articular fracture
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Loose body due to Synovial Chondromatosis.

choices.text: Secondary arthritis due to TB hip

questions.text: Absolute contraindication of total hip replacement in adults is:
questions.solution:
Absolute Contraindications for Total Hip Replacement (THR):

  • Active Infection (Option B):
    • Description: Active infection of the hip joint or any other region.
    • Rationale: Increases risk of postoperative infections and complications.

Relative contraindications for THR

  • Unstable Medical Illnesses:
    • Description: Any unstable medical conditions that significantly increase the risk of morbidity or mortality.
    • Rationale: May affect the patient's ability to recover from surgery.
  • Asymptomatic Bacteriuria:
    • Description: Presence of bacteria in the urine without symptoms.
    • Rationale: Not associated with increased risk of surgical site infections and is considered a relative contraindication.

Considerations for Specific Conditions:

Healed Tuberculosis (TB) of the Hip: (Option A)

  • Preoperative Requirements:
    • Complete Course of Antitubercular Therapy (ATT): Ensure TB infection is fully treated.
    • Synovial Fluid Biopsy: To rule out latent infection before surgery.
  • Conclusion: Not an absolute contraindication if these conditions are met.

Tom-Smith Arthritis (Sequelae of Septic Arthritis in Infancy): (Option C)

  • Description: Condition where the head of the femur is resorbed due to early septic arthritis, leading to future arthritis.
  • Treatment Considerations:
    • After Infection Resolution: THR is a viable option once skeletal growth is complete and latent infection has been ruled out.

Option A & C: Tom smith and TB Arthritis are Relative contraindications.

Key takeaway:

Active infection is only absolute contraindication to total hip replacement. Healed Tb, Tom smith arthritis and asymptomatic bacteriuria are relative contraindications.

questions.text: A 68 yr lady complains of severe knee pain and difficulty in walking and stair climbing. Pain in gradual onset, relieved with rest and aggravates on walking. Standing x-ray of both knees reveals osteo-arthritis. All of these are radiological features of OA except:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of osteoarthritis is mainly radiological. The following are the radiological features:

  • Narrowing of joint space, often limited to a part of the joint e.g., may be limited to the medial compartment of the tibiofemoral joint of the knee. (Option B)
  • Subchondral sclerosis - dense bone under the articular surface (Option A)
  • Subchondral cysts
  • Osteophyte formation - Image 2 (Option C)
  • Loose bodies
  • Deformity of the joint

Key Takeaway -

OA Radiographic Changes:

  • Narrowing of Joint Space
  • Osteophyte formation
  • Subchondral Sclerosis

choices.text: Pain and tenderness in sacro-iliac region
Rugger jersey spine on x ray

questions.text: All are true regarding ankylosing spondylitis except-
questions.solution:
Ankylosing Spondylitis and HLA-B27 Association

A strong association has been identified between the genetic marker HLA-B27 and ankylosing spondylitis.

Key Features and Progression:

  • (Option C) - Initial Joint Involvement: The sacroiliac joints are typically the first to be affected, followed by the spine progressing upward from the lumbar region. Hip, knee, manubriosternal joints involved frequently.
  • (Option A) - Ocular Involvement: Approximately 25% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis experience at least one episode of acute iritis.

Radiological Findings (X-ray of the Lumbar Spine):

  • Squaring of Vertebrae: Loss of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body due to calcification of the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Loss of Lumbar Lordosis: Flattening of the natural curve in the lumbar region.
  • Bridging Osteophytes (Syndesmophytes): Bony outgrowths connecting adjacent vertebrae.
  • (Option B) - Bamboo Spine Appearance: The spine takes on a rigid, bamboo-like appearance due to extensive syndesmophyte formation and vertebral fusion leading to stiffness.
  • There is also evidence of enthesopathy- calcification at the attachment of the muscles, tendons and ligaments, particularly around the pelvis and around the heel.

Ankylosing spondylitis Radiological Finding:

Option A, B & C: Chances of developing acute iritis, Stiff spine & Pain and tenderness in sacro-iliac region all three features seen in AS.

Option D: Rugger jersey spine is seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Key Takeaway -

Spine Appearance in various diseases:

  • Bamboo spine - Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Rugger Jersey spine - Hyperparathyroidism
  • Picture frame vertebra - paget's disease.

questions.text: All of the following are different surgical approaches to do primary total knee replacement except:
questions.solution:
Surgical approaches used for doing primary total knee replacement surgery are:

  1. Medial parapatellar (most common) (Option A)
  2. Subvastus (Option B)
  3. Mid-vastus (Option D)
  4. Lateral para patellar (least common)

Quadriceps Snip Approach in Knee Surgery

  • Purpose: Primarily used in revision knee replacement surgery to address fibrotic scarring after primary knee replacement.
  • Applications:
    • Commonly employed in revision knee arthroplasty and for treating stiff knees.
    • Best suited when stiffness originates from proximal causes; if stiffness is distal, a tibial tubercle osteotomy is preferable.
  • Technique:
    • Simple and straightforward to perform, offering good joint exposure in most revision cases or ankylosed knees.
    • Involves cutting the rectus tendon at or near the musculotendinous junction at a 45° angle proximally and laterally, aligned with the vastus lateralis muscle fibers.
    • The tendon should be fully divided, with reattachment of all muscle fibers at the end of the procedure.

Option A, B & D: Medial Parapatellar, Subvastus and Midvastus all 3 approaches are used in primary TKR.

Option C: Quadriceps Snips Surgery approach Primarily used in revision knee replacement surgery to address fibrotic scarring after primary knee replacement.

Key Takeaway -

  • Medial Parapatellar, Subvastus and Midvastus all 3 approaches are used in primary TKR.
  • Quadriceps Snips Surgery approach Primarily used in revision knee replacement surgery to address fibrotic scarring after primary knee replacement.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Option A, B, C and D are correctly matched in the table

Osteochondritis Dissecans (OCD)

  • Definition: A joint disorder where a segment of bone and cartilage become detached due to insufficient blood supply.
  • Commonly Affected Areas: Knee, elbow, ankle.
  • Symptoms: Pain, swelling, joint stiffness, and possible loose bodies in the joint.
  • Causes: Likely due to repetitive stress, trauma, or genetic factors.
  • Diagnosis: Via physical exam and imaging (X-rays, MRI).
  • Treatment: Includes rest, physical therapy, pain management, and possibly surgery.
  • Prognosis: Early treatment often leads to good outcomes; severe cases may require surgery.

Key Takeaway -

Imp Osteochondritis:

  • Koehler - Navicular
  • Freiburg - Metatarsal head
  • Panner - Capitulum
  • Sever's - Calcaneal Tuberosity

questions.text: A young female presents with a loose, hard, mobile swelling in her left knee with complaints of occasional locking of knee joint as well. Investigation of choice for diagnosis of this condition is?
questions.solution:
Synovial Chondromatosis

Definition:

  • Synovial chondromatosis is a proliferative disorder of the synovial membrane in joints or bursae. It involves the transformation of synovial tissue into cartilaginous nodules or masses.

Key Characteristics:

  • Appearance: Can range from simple metaplasia (transformation of tissue type) of the synovial lining to the development of firm cartilaginous nodules.

Presentation:

  • Age Group: Typically affects individuals around 30 years old.
  • Symptoms: Common symptoms include joint pain, stiffness, and swelling.

Common Locations:

  • Knee: The knee joint is the most frequently affected site.

Imaging Findings:

  • X-rays: Show calcified loose bodies within the joint.
  • MRI: Detects precalcific cartilaginous loose bodies and provides more detailed imaging of the joint structure.
  • USG is of little or no use in synovial chondromatosis.
  • CT scan will give exact diagnosis but will be unable to pick up pre-calcified fragments.

Treatment:

  • Arthroscopic Resection: Removal of rice bodies (small, rounded calcified nodules) and the affected synovial tissue.
  • Synovectomy: Surgical removal of the synovial membrane to prevent recurrence.
  • Option A - X-rays: Show calcified loose bodies within the joint.
  • Option B - USG is of little or no use in synovial chondromatosis.
  • Option C - MRI: Detects precalcific cartilaginous loose bodies and provides more detailed imaging of the joint structure.
  • Option D - CT scan will give exact diagnosis but will be unable to pick up pre-calcified fragments.

Key Takeaway -

Biopsy of the loose bodies and synovium is gold standard but invasive hence MRI is the IOC in diagnosing Synovial chondromatosis.
